definition: that cannot be explained by the laws of science and that seems to involve gods or magic
events, forces or powers that cannot be explained by the laws of science and that seem to involve gods or magic
a line on a map that separates places where a particular feature of a language is different
the study of dialects
the art or work of preparing books, etc. for printing, especially of designing how text will appear when it is printed
to form an opinion about something based on the information or evidence that is available
not supporting one person or group more than another
made of tubes or of parts that are like tubes in shape
like a tube in shape
a substance that enters the body and starts a process that can cause disease. The body then usually produces antibodies to fight the antigens.
the narrow passage at the opening of the womb of a woman or female animal
the treatment of disease, especially cancer, with the use of chemical substances
an extreme allergic reaction to something that you eat or touch
a medical condition in which somebody has too few red cells or too little hemoglobin in their blood, making them look pale and feel weak

a mental illness causing somebody to control the amount of food they eat in an extreme way that leads to dangerous weight loss, usually because they have an intense fear of getting fat and believe they are fat when they are not
designed to stop viruses such as HIV damaging the body
used to treat diseases caused by a virus
a serious condition in which parts of the body, usually the lungs, hurt because of an infection caused by fungi
the loss of full control of the body’s movements
made weaker or less effective
very thin
relating to the liver
a medical condition that causes severe loss of blood from even a slight injury because the blood fails to clot normally. It usually affects only men although it can be passed on by women.

a serious disease of the liver. There are three main forms: hepatitis A, the least serious, caused by infected food (= containing harmful bacteria), and hepatitis B and hepatitis C, both very serious and caused by infected blood.
the process by which chemical structures are broken down and energy is released
the officer who commands all the armed forces of a country or all its forces in a particular area
a person who commands all the armed forces of a country, especially one who has political as well as military power
to provide something good to balance or reduce the bad effects of damage, loss, etc.
to act in order to balance or correct something wrong or not normal
to pay somebody money because they have suffered some damage, loss, injury, etc.
a Japanese system of writing based on Chinese symbols, called characters; a symbol in this system
an extremely small living thing that you can only see under a microscope and that may cause disease
a meeting at which something, especially a new product or idea, or piece of work, is shown to a group of people
the act of showing something or of giving something to somebody
the way in which something is offered, shown, explained, etc. to others
the series of computer slides (= images) that are shown with the talk when somebody gives a presentation at a meeting
a ceremony or formal occasion during which a gift or prize is given
a performance of a play, etc. in a theatre
the position in which a baby is lying in the mother’s body just before birth

a serious disease in which the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord develop an infection and become swollen (= larger than normal), causing severe headache, a high temperature and sometimes death
a parasite found in water that causes infections inside the body
a well-known phrase or sentence that gives advice or says something that is generally true, for example ‘Waste not, want not.’
the fact of staying where you are or delaying doing something until somebody/something comes or something happens
the job of working as a waiter or waitress
the fact of large amounts of water covering an area that is usually dry
a very large number of things or people
a group of atoms that forms the smallest unit that a substance can be divided into without a change in its chemical nature
to take the outer layer off fruit, vegetables, etc.
to remove a layer, etc. from the surface of something; to come off the surface of something
to come off in narrow or small pieces
to lose narrow or small pieces of something that covers something
to look out for somebody/something that you might see
a round yellow-orange citrus fruit with a sharp taste, used in cooking or in drinks
a tree on which yuzus grow
fruit belonging to the group of fruit that includes oranges, lemons, limes and grapefruit
the season of summer
